awd_abstract_narration:
In this project, funded by the Chemical Structure, Dynamic & Mechanism B Program of the Chemistry Division, Professor Christian Wolf of the Department of Chemistry at Georgetown University is developing molecular probes for quantitative analysis of the amount, absolute configuration and enantiomeric composition of chiral compounds in complex samples.  Many pharmaceuticals are chiral compounds and their effective analysis is clearly important in developing new medicines.  This project could lead to new analysis methods that are compatible with modern workflow platforms, that can minimize waste production and operational costs, and that are applicable to automated parallel analysis of small scale reactions or biomarker sensing.  The project is highly collaborative, involving industrial and academic partners. It provides multiple training opportunities for graduate, undergraduate and high school students, including those from underrepresented groups.

The specific goals are to introduce and test several molecular probes that are designed to capture a chiral target either by covalent bond formation or noncovalent interactions and to then translate the molecular recognition event via spontaneous substrate-controlled chirality amplification across the stereodynamic receptor scaffold into a distinct chiroptical response. The prospects of this research are multifaceted and include important applications such as direct asymmetric reaction analysis or quantification of medicinally relevant biomarkers. Comprehensive optical sensing (determination of absolute configuration, enantiomeric purity and concentration of chiral substrates) is to be achieved using conceptually new molecular recognition and chiral amplification strategies.  These strategies utilize stereodynamic cup-shaped architectures, foldamers, axially chiral reporter units, molecular propellers, multicomponent assemblies, dynamic covalent chemistry, organocatalysis, frustrated Lewis pairs, and tropos ligand derived metal complexes.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Many biologically active compounds, including pharmaceuticals, agrochemicals, flavors and nutrients, are chiral. This means they exist in the form of enantiomers (non-superimposable mirror images) which often show different biological properties and pharmacological effects. As a result, the majority of today's top-selling drugs are marketed as single enantiomers. The general importance of chiral compound research and the need to efficiently screen a large chemical space to find optimal results requires methods that are compatible with high-throughput experimentation equipment and parallel data acquisition. Broadly available and routinely used technology enables chemists to produce hundreds of chiral compound samples literally overnight. By contrast, the stereochemical analysis of these samples is typically a major bottleneck that severely limits the discovery pace and progress in chemical and pharmaceutical development projects. With this NSF award (Chiroptical Sensing with Stereodynamic Probes, CHE 1764135), the Wolf research group at Georgetown University has developed optical sensing assays applicable to fast high-throughput analysis of large chiral sample numbers while addressing economical, operational and sustainability aspects that are increasingly important in academic and industrial laboratories including miniaturization of reaction/analysis platforms, and reduction of the overall workload, costs and waste production. The general utility, speed, robustness, superior time-efficiency and compatibility with automated sample handling and modern chemometrics have been demonstrated multiple times with a large variety of chiral compounds. The successful testing of this rising methodology in accelerated asymmetric reaction screening and natural compound analysis, which are important tasks in the pharmaceutical business, demonstrates its readiness for prime use in the field. In addition, machine learning tools have been introduced to expand optical sensing methodology toward the analysis of very complex mixtures which eliminates the common need to isolate individual compounds prior to the analysis.

The collaborative and interdisciplinary nature of this research program has provided multiple opportunities for the training of two high school, four undergraduate and nine graduate students, of which many are from groups that are underrepresented in the sciences. They have been involved in academic and industrial partnerships with colleagues at Merck in Rahway NJ, at the University of Texas at Austin and at the University of Bologna, Italy, which significantly enhanced the research and educational infrastructure available to students at Georgetown University. The students have developed a thorough understanding of various aspects of analytical, inorganic and organic chemistry and they have found multiple opportunities to present and discuss their research projects, for example with talks or posters at meetings of the American Chemical Society, the Gordon Research Conference and a local synthesis symposium. They have received intra- and extramural travel grants as well as other awards and are co-authors of many peer-reviewed publications and patent applications. The diverse research experience and training in the PI's group along with the involvement in international and industrial collaborative projects have fostered their fascination for the chemical sciences and positively impacted their careers past graduation.
